contextId.information: This is an idiom. AT: "had finished" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom speaks of sexual activity as though the bodies that are together become one body. AT: "their two bodies will become one body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"your eyes will open." This idiom means "you will become aware of things" or "you will understand new things." This meaning can be stated clearly. AT: "It will be as though your eyes were opened" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means that the expression on his face showed that he was angry or jealous. Some languages have an idiom that describes what a person's face looks like when he is angry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"attacked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The term "your face" represents God's presence. AT: "I will not be able to speak to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: I will be hidden from your face

contextId.information: Even though Yahweh is everywhere, this idiom speaks of Cain as though he went far away. AT: "went away from where Yahweh spoke to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: went out from the presence of Yahweh

contextId.information: This idiom means Yahweh spoke. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This idiom means God spoke. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:15:01|15:1]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "Abraham slept deeply" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom. AT: "many possessions" or "great wealth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"greatly increase the number of your descendants" or "give you very many descendants" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means "will cause him to have many children." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"I would never want you to do something like that" or "You should not want to do something like that" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Far be it from you to do such a thing

contextId.information: "Yahweh departed" or "Yahweh left" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Lot spoke in a friendly way to the men of the city hoping that they would listen to him. AT: "my friends" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

"and now he thinks he has the right to tell us what is right and what is wrong" or "but we are not going to allow him to stop us from doing what we want to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: and now he has become our judge

contextId.information: The men are angry that Lot said, "Do not act so wickedly" ([[:en:bible:notes:gen:19:06|19:7]]), so they are threatening to act more wickedly than Lot had feared at first. AT: "we will act more wickedly with you than we will with them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: we will deal worse with you than with them

contextId.information: This is a way of telling them to run so that they do not die. AT: "Run away and save your lives!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This tells why God rescued Lot. To "call to mind" is a way of saying "remember." This does not imply that God forgot about Abraham. It means he considered Abraham and had mercy on him. AT: "God thought about Abraham and had mercy on him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a strong way of saying the king will die. AT: "you will certainly die soon" or "I will kill you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a way of saying "I make all of my land available to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the phrase "was with" is an idiom that means God helped or blessed the boy. AT: "God guided the boy" or "God blessed the boy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the phrase "is with you" is an idiom that means God helps or blesses Abraham. AT: "God blesses everything you do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: God is with you in all that you do

contextId.information: This is an idiom meaning to make a solemn oath witnessed by a higher authority, in this instance, God. AT: "promise me with God as your witness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: swear to me here by God

contextId.information: The phrase "Do no lay your hand upon" is a way of saying "do not harm." God said basically the same thing twice to emphasize that Abraham should not hurt Isaac. AT: "Do not hurt the boy in any way" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: Do not lay your hand upon the lad, nor do anything to harm him

contextId.information: This is an idiom. This probably means "a powerful man" (UDB) or "a mighty leader." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This means that after Abraham died, his soul went to the same place as his relatives who died before him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he joined his family members who had already died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: he was gathered to his people

contextId.information: This means that after Ishmael died, his soul went to the same place as his relatives who died before him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he joined his family members who had already died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
It was common to speak of leaving the promised land as "going down" to another place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Do not go down to Egypt

contextId.information: Here "touches" means to touch in a harmful way. AT: "Whoever harms this man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

This phrase refers to a natural spring they uncovered when they were digging a new well. It provided a continuous flow of fresh drinking water. AT: "fresh water" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "see here" adds emphasis to what follows. AT: "Listen carefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This adds emphasis to what Isaac says next. AT: "Listen" or "Pay attention to what I am about to tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The phrase "daughters of the land" means the local females. AT: "like these women who live in this land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: like these women, some of the daughters of the land

contextId.information: Here "mouth" is a way of referring to an opening. AT: "the opening of the well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "mouth" is a way of referring to an opening. AT: "the well" or "the opening of the well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is a way of saying that the child that Bilhah gives birth to will belong to Rachel. AT: "for me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "wrestlings have I wrestled" is an idiom used for emphasis. It is also a metaphor that speaks of Rachel's attempts to have a child like her sister as if she were having a physical fight with Leah. AT: "I have had a great struggle to have children like my older sister, Leah" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: With mighty wrestlings have I wrestled with my sister

contextId.information: Here the phrase "in the days of" is an idiom that refers to the season or time of year. AT: "at the time of year of the wheat harvest" or "during the wheat harvest" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: in the days of wheat harvest

contextId.information: The phrase "call to mind" means to remember. This does not mean God forgot about Rachel. It means he considered her request. AT: "God considered Rachel and granted to her what she wanted" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: God called Rachel to mind and listened to her

contextId.information: This is a way of saying "Look up." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "into the hand" means to give control over them. AT: "He divided them into small herds, and gave each of his servants control over one herd" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: These he gave these into the hand of his servants, every herd by itself

contextId.information: This is a way of saying that Jacob did not say or do anything about the matter. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
A "dying breath" is a person's last breath before he or she dies. AT: "Just before she died, as she was taking her last breath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: As she was dying, with her dying breath

contextId.information: This means that after Isaac died, his soul went to the same place as his relatives who died before him. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he joined his family members who had already died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that this was the city where he lived. AT: "the name of the city where he lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that this was the city where he lived. AT: "The name of the city where he lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that this was the city where he lived. AT: "The name of the city where he lived" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means that Joseph was born when Israel was an old man. AT: "who was born when Israel was an old man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The means that he kept thinking about the meaning of Joseph's dream. AT: "kept thinking about what the dream might mean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Israel wants Joseph to come back and tell him about how his brother and flocks are doing. AT: "come tell me what you find out" or "give me a report" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This wording shows that the brothers acted upon their plans. AT: "So now" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This means not to harm or injure him. AT: "not hurt him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: not lay our hands upon him

contextId.information: The phrase "in the sight" refers to Yahweh seeing Onan's wickedness. AT: "was evil and Yahweh saw it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: was evil in the sight of Yahweh

contextId.information: Travelling to Egypt is always considered as going "down" in contrast to going "up" to the promised land. This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Ishmaelites had taken Joseph to Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: Joseph was brought down to Egypt

contextId.information: This means that the master saw how Yahweh was helping Joseph. AT: "His master saw that Yahweh was helping him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: His master saw that Yahweh was with him

contextId.information: "To find favor" means to be approved by someone. The idiom "in his sight" refers to a person's opinion. Possible meanings are 1) AT: "Potiphar was pleased with Joseph" or 2) AT: "Yahweh was pleased with Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: Joseph found favor in his sight

contextId.information: This refers to how Yahweh took care of Joseph and was kind to him. AT: "But Yahweh was kind to Joseph" (UDB) or "But Yahweh took care of Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This refers to how Yahweh helped Joseph and guided him. AT: "because Yahweh guided Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

The phrase "put you over" means to give authority. Here "land" refers to the people. AT: "I put you in charge of everyone in Egypt" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: I have put you over all the land of Egypt

contextId.information: The phrase "put you over" means to give authority. Here "land" refers to the people. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:41:39|41:41]]. AT: "I put you in charge of everyone in Egypt"(See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
contextId.quote: Pharaoh put him over all the land

contextId.information: To "bring down ... to Sheol" is way of saying they will cause him to die and go to Sheol. He uses the word "down" because it was commonly believed sheol is somewhere underground. AT: "then you will cause me, an old man, to die of sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: then you will bring down my gray hair with sorrow to Sheol

contextId.information: To "bring down ... to Sheol" is way of saying they will cause him to die and go to Sheol. He uses the word "down" because it was commonly believed Sheol is somewhere underground. AT: "then you will cause me, an old man, to die of sorrow" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: you will bring down my gray hair with sorrow to Sheol

contextId.information: The phrase "close you eyes with his own hand" is a way of saying that Joseph will be present when Israel dies and it will be Joseph who will close Jacob's eyelids at the time of his death. AT: "And Joseph will even be present with you at the time of your death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: and Joseph will close your eyes with his own hand

contextId.information: This means that someone is approved of by someone else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is an idiom that means God will help and bless the people of Israel. AT: "God will help you" or "God will bless you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The term "he collapsed" is an idiom for being overcome. AT: "that he fell on his father in grief" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: that he collapsed on the face of his father

contextId.information: This is an idiom that means that someone is approved of by someone else. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This expression means that Joseph adopted these children of Machir as his own children. This means they would have special inheritance rights from Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
contextId.quote: who were placed on the knees of Joseph
